title.value: scCross: A Deep Generative Model for Unifying Single-cell Multi-omics with Seamless Integration, Cross-modal Generation, and In-silico Exploration
title.justification: This is the full title of the research paper which summarizes the focus of the study.
title.quote: scCross: A Deep Generative Model for Unifying Single-cell Multi-omics with Seamless Integration, Cross-modal Generation, and In-silico Exploration

extractions.description: This paper introduces scCross, a tool engineered using variational autoencoder, generative adversarial network principles, and the Mutual Nearest Neighbors (MNN) technique for modality alignment in single-cell multi-omics. The tool is designed for seamless integration of varied single-cell multi-omics data, and it also excels in generating cross-modal data, simulating multi-omics data, and performing in-silico cellular perturbations.

type.justification: The paper focuses on the development, implementation, and evaluation of the scCross model using empirical data and results.
type.quote: The results, depicted in Fig. 2a-e, shed light on scCross’s ability not only to generate but also to uphold the biological nuances of the original data. The UMAP visualization...

name.justification: The research focuses on computational methods for integrating and analyzing single-cell multi-omics data
name.quote: We introduce scCross: a tool adeptly engineered using variational autoencoder, generative adversarial network principles, and the Mutual Nearest Neighbors (MNN) technique for modality alignment.

name.justification: The study specifically deals with multi-omics data integration, generation, and simulation.
name.quote: This synergy ensures seamless integration of varied single-cell multi-omics data.

name.justification: The paper utilizes variational autoencoders and generative adversarial networks, which are ML techniques.
name.quote: scCross employs the Variational autoencoder (VAE)-Generative adversarial network (GAN) deep generative framework.

name.justification: scCross is the primary model introduced and discussed extensively in the paper.
name.quote: We introduce scCross: a tool adeptly engineered using variational autoencoder, generative adversarial network principles, and the Mutual Nearest Neighbors (MNN) technique for modality alignment.

is_contributed.justification: scCross is introduced and detailed in the paper.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed on actual datasets as evidenced by the detailed results and evaluations provided.
is_executed.quote: To showcase its prowess and endorse its robustness and evaluate the method’s performance in situations with limited or partial single-cell data of another modality of interest, we divided the matched mouse cortex dataset [31] into two parts — 20% for training and the remainder for testing.

is_compared.justification: scCross is compared numerically to other state-of-the-art single-cell data integration methods.
is_compared.quote: We benchmarked scCross against several state-of-the-art single-cell data integration methods, including Seurat v4, scglue, and uniPort.

referenced_paper_title.value: scCross: A Deep Generative Model for Unifying Single-cell Multi-omics with Seamless Integration, Cross-modal Generation, and In-silico Exploration
referenced_paper_title.justification: The model is introduced in this paper.

name.justification: The Human Cell Atlas dataset is used for large-scale integration involving millions of cells.
name.quote: In our evaluation of scCross’s integrative capabilities, we tapped into over four million human single-cell atlases, consisting of gene expression data for four million cells and chromatin accessibility data for 0.7 million cells.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This matches the description in the Human Cell Atlas initiative.
referenced_paper_title.quote: the human cell atlas dataset is obtained from Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) repository under the following accession numbers GSE156793 for scRNA-seq and GSE149683 for scATAC-seq

name.justification: The matched mouse cortex dataset is used as the primary dataset for training and validation.
name.quote: Utilizing the unmatched mouse cortex dataset to train our model.

referenced_paper_title.value: High-throughput sequencing of the transcriptome and chromatin accessibility in the same cell
referenced_paper_title.justification: This details the correct reference for the matched mouse cortex dataset used.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The matched mouse cortex dataset is obtained from the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) repository under the accession numbers GSE126074.

name.justification: A comprehensive COVID-19 dataset comprising scRNA-seq and protein (CITE-Seq) data is used for in-silico perturbations.
name.quote: In our endeavor to showcase the capabilities of scCross, we highlight its expertise in conducting in-silico multi-omic perturbations. These capabilities not only enable the exploration of potential intervention strategies for cellular state manipulation but also provide insights into the intricacies of molecular responses, particularly those seen in COVID-19 infections using the single-cell multi-omic dataset derived from a comprehensive study.

referenced_paper_title.value: Single-cell multi-omics analysis of the immune response in COVID-19
referenced_paper_title.justification: This accurately represents the referenced paper for the COVID-19 dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The COVID-19 dataset used in the study is obtained from the website at covid19.cog.sanger.ac.uk.

name.justification: Scanpy was used for multiple steps including clustering and visualization.
name.quote: We utilize the Scanpy package for this purpose (v.1.8.2), generating a UMAP plot depicted in Fig. 4.

name.justification: epiScanpy was used for the analysis of snmC-seq and scATAC-seq data.
name.quote: SnmC-seq data transitions through a sequence of normalization, log-transformation, scaling, and PCA, utilizing epiScanpy (v.0.4.0).
